bestBHT.bht: Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow and flourish without toiling or spinning, without human care. These lilies, whether they be crown imperials or other wild flowers, serve as a beautiful example of nature's abundance, reminding us of God's providence. Just as the birds in the sky, we must take the time to observe and appreciate the growth and beauty of these flowers, a reflection of God's marvelous creation. Let us learn from these delicate flowers, finding rest and trust in God, knowing that He provides for us just as He provides for the lilies.

Henry Alford: Consider, implying more attention than 'Behold.' The birds fly by, and we can but look upon them: the flowers are ever with us, and we can watch their growth.

These lilies have been supposed to be the crown imperial, (fritillaria imperialis,) which grows wild in Palestine, or the amaryllis lutea, (Sir J. KE. Smith,) whose golden liliaceous flowers cover the autumnal fields of the Levant.
Probably, however, the word here may be taken in a wider import, as signifying all wild flowers.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Consider—observe well the lilies of the field, how they grow: they toil not—as men, planting and preparing the flax."
Philip Schaff: Consider, i.e., study, observe closely; more readily done in the case of the plants than in that of the birds.
The lilies of the field, i.e., wild lilies, growing without human care.
How they grow. So beautifully, luxuriantly, without human care.
Archibald T. Robertson: The lilies of the field (τα κρινα του αγρου). The word may include other wild flowers besides lilies, blossoms like anemones, poppies, gladioli, irises (McNeile).
John Gill: Consider the lilies of the field...Look upon, with their eyes, consider and contemplate in their minds, how they grow; in what variety of garbs they appear, of what different beautiful colours, and fragrant odours, they were.
...they toil not, or do not labour as husbandmen do, in tilling their land, ploughing their fields, and sowing them with flax, out of which linen garments are made.
Neither do they spin; the flax, when plucked and dressed, as women do, in order for clothing; nor do they weave it into cloth, or make it up into garments, as other artificers do.

bhtAttempts.bht: Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow and flourish without toiling or spinning, without human care. These lilies, whether they be crown imperials or other wild flowers, serve as a beautiful example of nature's abundance, reminding us of God's providence. Just as the birds in the sky, we must take the time to observe and appreciate the growth and beauty of these flowers, a reflection of God's marvelous creation. Let us learn from these delicate flowers, finding rest and trust in God, knowing that He provides for us just as He provides for the lilies.

Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow and flourish without toiling or spinning. These wild flowers, such as crown imperials or other blossoms, showcase the abundance and beauty of nature. By observing their growth, we can appreciate God's providence and trust in His provision. Similar to the birds of the sky, we are called to study and admire the lilies, finding solace in their simplicity and learning to rest in God's care.

Consider the lilies of the field and their growth, devoid of toil or spinning. These lilies, encompassing various wildflowers and possibly crown imperials, demonstrate the splendor of nature and God's providential care. Just like watching birds in flight, we are advised to carefully observe and appreciate the lilies' beauty, finding assurance in God's provisions. By studying these delicate flowers, we gain wisdom and learn to trust in His abundant care for us, acknowledging that He meets our needs without our ceaseless striving.
